ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the fundamentals to linear transformations and the relationship between linear equations, linear maps and how they can be used to study geometric spaces.
Basic understanding of how matrices look like. How to row reduce, project, and how to find eigenvalues.
I developed a solid understanding of matrices, how to manipulate them, and what they and the manipulations actually represent.
Linear algebra techniques -- matrices, Gaussian elimination, least squares approximation, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, etc.

I thought I learned--and the class did a very good job about teaching--both much of the algebra behind linear algebra, but also a more conceptual lens of how to visualize the subjects we discussed. I think I now have a much stronger grasp of how to apply linear algebra in other classes/circumstances.

After taking Math S222, I've got a basic understanding of linear algebra. I learnt matrix operations and the way to solve a linear system; I knew the concept of vector space and linear transformation, then some more in-depth knowledge of matrices, like orthogonalization, determinant, and eigenvalue. Also, linear algrbra enables me to simplify my calculation in solving linear equations. This course has developed my insight into "linear transformation".
I learned the main concepts in linear algebra.
learned everything about matrix.
I learned the fundamental concepts of linear algebra surrounding implications and applications of solving systems of linear equations.
Linear algebra.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths are in the computational focus. I think it could be improved by introducing each new algebraic concept simultaneously with the  geometric interpretation.

Accelerated math classes can never be as good as the class during the normal semester but I believe James had a decent way of condensing the class. The concept of the four fundamental subspaces did not have enough explanation and we didn't really get to cover the spectral theorem fully either. One can only cover so much in 5 weeks.
This course was very strong. The only thing that I wished had been different was that I wish we had had more time to learn about the Spectral Theorem and Singular Value Decomposition at the end.
The course was very accessible regardless of prior math experience, which was nice. It moved a bit slowly and could possibly be improved by quickening the pace and introducing more topics.

I think this course is successful in laying the foundation of linear algebra for students. It covers the knowledge in a comprehensive way and I think I've mastered basic knowledge of linear algebra after this course even if the course itself is compressed and fast-paced. 
However, I think the course still has something to improve. In my opinion, the introduction of matrix multiplication, a crucial concept in linear algebra, is a little abrupt in this course. I think matrix multiplication is a generalization of matrix multiplying a vector, and the result of "a matrix multiplying a vector" is abstracted from linear equations. Therefore I think there might be some more detailed depiction of matrix multiplication, which can help lay a more solid foundation for students. Also, from my point of view, the introduction of linear transformation is also a little bit too fast-paced and maybe too early. In the last few lessons, this concept is frequently used, so I was a little frustrated at that time. So I think the order of the lessons can be moderated a little bit.

The expectations of the course were communicated well, and it was very thorough in its scope.  The main weakness is that there were problems due every day on content learned the day before, which limits one's opportunities to ask questions before turning in graded work.
Loved the mid class breaks. Didnt like the difficulty of daily homework

The strength of this course is that it meets every day, which allows for shorter and more regular lectures. One weakness of the course was that since the problem sets were assigned one day and due the next, it could sometimes be difficult to get help if needed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure, the material is important and it's well taught.

No, not in a compressed summer timeline! Prof James is an entertaining and a good professor but 222 in a summer format is TERRIBLE. There is daily class with daily p sets and weekly tests which really add up. If you are taking a non-gut 2nd summer session class, this is torturous. There is no time for catchup and you will be spending several hours on the class each day, which is not always possible/you may not want to do it some days. This class is probably 10x more manageable if taught during the school year since overall the tests were fair and Prof James' handouts were super helpful. Another annoying thing is that the HWs are worth a large part of the grade, but it is hard to consistently get high grades on them when they are daily, not much time to check answers, and there are no answer keys.
Yes. It's a great way to get a prereq out of the way. Wouldn't recommend if you really want to learn linear.
I would recommend this course. The course was well designed, well taught, interesting, and mind-expanding while not overly challenging (most of what we learned was very concrete).

Yes, if you're interested in the computational aspects of linear algebra, this is a great course with a manageable level of difficulty. James made class time engaging and was always available to answer questions, so that made the experience good.
Yes. I thought the class did a good job at introducing the fundamentals but also introducing how to properly think about and use them.
Yes.  If you need to learn linear algebra and aren't a math major, this is a good course to take.
Not really but if taking it its probably required.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in learning linear algebra over the summer. The time scale of the course is compressed, but the course doesn't feel rushed.
